R Group Flyer

Author

Russell Almond

Published

February 29, 2020

FSU R User Group

R is a free (both as in speech and as in beer) software package that allows for statistical analyses ranging from the simple to the complex, with support for great graphics.

We will be covering the R tidyverse series of commands which makes R easier to use for people with little programming experience. The text will be R for Data Science which is available for free at https://r4ds.had.co.nz/.

Details

  • Meetings Fridays at 3:45 in the LRC (Stone Building, 1301A).

  • No prior experience with R is necessary.

  • Sessions will be recorded so you can catch up if you miss a week.

  • Open to Grads, Undergrads, Faculty and Staff

Getting R on your laptop

Although the LRC has computers available, you will probably want to install R on your own computer. Here are instructions for various kinds of computers.

There are three things you need to get: * R — this is the base program that does the calculations. * RStudio — this is a development environment which makes writing and running R scripts easier. It also has tools for building papers and presentations using R. * tidyverse — these are a series of packages which make the data analysis flow in R easier.

Download from https://cloud.r-project.org/

This is the source distribution. Select the installation method for your platform.

Download for Debian (Ubuntu/Pop OS) linux

Use the following command:
sudo apt-get install r-base

You can also use sudo apt-get install rstudio to get RStudio.

Download for Red Hat (CentOS) linux

First, you need to configure the EPEL repositories. (In CentOS, this can be done with sudo yum install -y epel-release

Then, you can install:
sudo yum install -y R

Install using homebrew (Mac OS X)

Assuming you have home brew installed, R can be installed using:
sudo brew install r

I think RStudio is available from homebrew, but I don’t know the recipe.

Install using Chocolatey (Windows)

Assumeing you have chocolatey installed, R can be installed using:
choco install r.project

Note that you need to be running the powershell as admin to do installations with chocolatey.

You can also do choco install r.studio to get R Studio.

RStudio

RStudio is an integrated development environment (IDE) for R. That means it is a wrap around program that runs R inside it. At the same time it provides a number of tools to make working in R easier. These include:

  • Editor for R code and scripts that is aware of R syntax.
  • Debugging Tools
  • Ways of saving graphs and tables.
  • Integration with source code control systems (git and svn).
  • A special way of writing reports and slides with integrated R code.

There are other IDEs for R, but this is the one we recommend. It is available from https://RStudio.com/.

Tidyverse

The R system comes with the ability to add packages. There are 15,382 packages available for R, many of which are useful.

The tidyverse series of packages which make the normal data analysis flow work much more easily. These are used in the book we are following.

To install using RStudio: From the menubar select “Tools” followed by “Install Packages…”. Then type “tidyverse”. Make sure the “Install Dependencies” box is checked.

To install from the R command line, type install.packages("tidyverse") then return. R will prompt for a mirror site to download from. All will work, but pick one in the US for fastest speed.
